intro: Fimbristylis hispidula, commonly known as the hairy sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its triangular stems and narrow leaves. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Fimbristylis hispidula produces small, clustered flowers that are usually green or brown, and it is often found in coastal areas or along waterways. Its hairy texture and adaptability make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
